en: Mrs. Dashwood remained at Norland several months; not from any disinclination to move when the sight of every well known spot ceased to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while; for when her spirits began to revive, and her mind became capable of some other exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy remembrances, she was impatient to be gone, and indefatigable in her inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible. But she could hear of no situation that at once answered her notions of comfort and ease, and suited the prudence of her eldest daughter, whose steadier judgment rejected several houses as too large for their income, which her mother would have approved.

Had he ever been in the way of learning, I think he would have drawn very well. Willoughby may undoubtedly have very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has. But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at once. Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at its being practiced by him."

en: The evening passed off in the equal indulgence of feeling. She played over every favourite song that she had been used to play to Willoughby, every air in which their voices had been oftenest joined, and sat at the instrument gazing on every line of music that he had written out for her, till her heart was so heavy that no farther sadness could be gained; and this nourishment of grief was every day applied. She spent whole hours at the pianoforte alternately singing and crying; her voice often totally suspended by her tears. In books too, as well as in music, she courted the misery which a contrast between the past and present was certain of giving. She read nothing but what they had been used to read together.

en: "I am convinced," said Edward, "that you really feel all the delight in a fine prospect which you profess to feel. But, in return, your sister must allow me to feel no more than I profess. I like a fine prospect, but not on picturesque principles. I do not like crooked, twisted, blasted trees. I admire them much more if they are tall, straight, and flourishing. I do not like ruined, tattered cottages. I am not fond of nettles or thistles, or heath blossoms. I have more pleasure in a snug farm‚Äìhouse than a watch‚Äìtower‚Äîand a troop of tidy, happy villages please me better than the finest banditti in the world."

But I am very glad to find it was only my own fancy, and that you really do not blame me. en: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister‚Äîbut what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self‚Äìreproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

Cuando vine a verla la semana pasada y la encontr√© sola, estaba decidido a saber la verdad, aunque a√∫n indeciso en cuanto a qu√© hacer cuando la supiera. Mi comportamiento debe haberle extra√±ado, pero ahora lo entender√°. Tener que verlas a todas ustedes enga√±adas en esa forma; ver a su hermana... pero, ¬øqu√© pod√≠a hacer? No ten√≠a esperanza alguna de intervenir con √©xito; y en ocasiones pensaba que su hermana a√∫n pod√≠a mantener suficiente influencia sobre √©l para recuperarlo. Pero tras un trato tan ignominioso, ¬øqui√©n sabe cu√°les ser√≠an sus intenciones hacia ella? Cualesquiera hayan sido, sin embargo, puede que ahora ella se sienta agradecida de su situaci√≥n, y sin duda m√°s adelante lo estar√°, cuando la compare con la de mi pobre Eliza, cuando piense en la situaci√≥n miserable y desesperada de esta pobre ni√±a y se la imagine con un afecto tan fuerte por √©l, tan fuerte como el que ella misma le tiene, y con un esp√≠ritu atormentado por las autorrecriminaciones, que la acompa√±ar√°n durante toda su vida. Con toda seguridad esta comparaci√≥n le servir√° de algo. Sentir√° que sus propios sufrimientos no son nada. No provienen de una mala conducta y no pueden traerle desgracia. Al contrario, deber√°n hacer que en cada uno de sus amigos aumente la amistad hacia ella. La preocupaci√≥n por su desdicha y el respeto por la entereza que subyace a ella deber√°n reforzar todos los afectos. Utilice, sin embargo, su propia discreci√≥n para comunicarle lo que le he contado. Usted debe saber mejor qu√© efecto tendr√°; y si no hubiera cre√≠do muy seriamente y desde el fondo de mi coraz√≥n que pudiera serle de alguna utilidad, que pudiera aliviar sus padecimientos, no me habr√≠a permitido perturbarla con este relato de las aflicciones que ha debido sufrir mi familia, una narraci√≥n con la cual podr√≠a sospecharse que intento enaltecerme a costa de los dem√°s.

st: 'Me hona joale, ka pel'a sefahleho sa hao; E theko e boima, e mpe ho feta ka bobeli. Ho tseba sena sohle, joalo ka ha ke se ke se tseba libeke tse ngata, nahana hore na ke tlameha ho ikutloa joang ho bona khaitseli ea hau e le mo rata joalo ka leha e le neng, 'me ka ho kholiseha hore o ne a lokela ho mo nyala: nahana hore na ke tlameha ho ikutloa joang molemong oa hau kaofela. 11Ha ke etla ho lona bekeng e fetileng, mme ke o fumane ke le mong, ke ne ke ikemiseditse ho tseba nnete. Le ha ho le joalo, ha ke sa tsebe hore na ke eng eo u lokelang ho e etsa ha e tsejoa. Ka nako eo ho ne ho bonahala eka ke ntho e sa tloaelehang ho uena; Empa joale u tla utloisisa seo. Ho utloisoa bohloko bohle, e le hore bohle ba thetsehe; Ke ne ke tla etsa'ng ka mor'abo r≈çna?+ Empa ke ne ke tla etsa'ng? Ha ke na t≈°epo ea ho kena-kenana le katleho; Ka linako tse ling ke ne ke nahana hore t≈°usumetso ea khaitseli ea hau e ka 'na ea mo pholosa. Empa joale, ka mor'a t≈°ebeliso e joalo e sa hlekefetsang, ea ka bolelang hore na meralo ea hae e ne e le eng ho eena. Leha ho le joalo, leha ho le joalo, a kanna a ba teng hona joale, 'me ka mor'a moo a belaelang o tla retelehela ka teboho ho boemo ba hae ba hae, ha a bapisa le ea futsanehileng Eliza, ha a nka boemo bo sotoba le bo se nang t≈°epo ea ngoanana enoa ea futsanehileng, le lit≈°oant≈°o tsa hae ho eena, ka lerato ho eena le matla, a ntse a le matla joaloka eena,  'Me ka kelello e hlokofatsoa ke ho ipolaisa, e leng se lokelang ho ba teng ho eena ka bophelo. Ha e le hantle, papiso ena e tlameha ho ba le ts'ebeliso ea eona le eena. O tla utloa bohloko ba hae ha bo na letho. Ba ke ke ba hlola ba e-na le boit≈°oaro bo bobe, 'me ba ke ke ba tlisa nyeliso. Ho fapana le hoo, motsoalle e mong le e mong o tlameha ho ba motsoalle oa hae haholoanyane. Ho t≈°oenyeha ka ho hloka thabo le tlhompho ea hae ka tlas'a eona, ho tlameha ho matlafatsa boitlamo bo bong le bo bong. Leha ho le joalo, sebelisa bohlale ba hau ka ho buisana le eena seo ke u boleletseng sona. U lokela ho tseba hantle hore na ke eng e tla ba molemo ka ho fetisisa; Empa ha kea ka ka teba, 'me ho tloha ka pelo ea ka ho lumela hore e ka ba ea t≈°ebeletso, ka fokotsa ho ikoahlaea hae, Nka be ke sa utloa bohloko ka lebaka lena la mat≈°oenyeho a lelapa la ka, le ho ka 'na ha bonahala eka e ne e rerile ho nyolla ka lit≈°enyehelo tsa ba bang. tn: 13Mme jaanong sefatlhego sa gago se fa pele ga gago; Di a senyega, di a senyega, di bosula go feta tse pedi. Fa ke ne ke sa ntse ke itse dilo tseno tsotlhe, e re ka ke ne ke sa ntse ke itse gore ke tshwanetse go ikutlwa jang fa ke ne ke sa ntse ke mo rata e bile ke tlhomamisegile gore o tla mo nyala: akanya gore ke tshwanetse go ikutlwa jang ka ntlha ya lona lotlhe. 10 E rile ke tla kwa go lona beke e e fetileng, ke go fitlhela ke le esi, ka ititaya sehuba go itse boammaaruri. Le fa go ntse jalo, ba ne ba sa itse gore ke eng se se tshwanetseng go dirwa fa ba ne ba itse gore ba ka dira eng. Ka nako eo, boitshwaro jwa me bo ne bo lebega bo sa siama mo go wena; Jaanong o a tlhaloganya. 10Gore lo lwe bosula jotlhe, Ke ne ke batla go bona kgaitsadie mme ke ne ke tla dira eng? Ga ke na tsholofelo epe ya go nna le seabe mo go atlegeng ga me; Ka dinako tse dingwe, ke ne ke sa ntse ke akanya gore go ka nna le seabe mo go ene. Le fa go ntse jalo, morago ga go dirisa didirisiwa tseno tse di sa tshwaneng, ke mang yo o ka mmolelelang gore ke eng se a neng a se dira. Le fa go ntse jalo, le fa go ntse jalo, a ka tswa a le teng, mme morago ga moo, o tla nna le tebogo mo boemong jwa gagwe, fa a tshwantsha le tsa ga Elisa mohumanegi, fa a tsaya maemo a a utlwisang botlhoko a mosetsana yono yo o humanegileng, mme a mo leba ka lorato lo lo mo ratang thata, a sa ntse a le thata jaaka a le esi,  Le fa go ntse jalo, go na le motho yo o sa tshwanelang go nna le seabe mo go ene, o tshwanetse go nna le seabe mo go ene ka botshelo. Le fa go ntse jalo, go tshwanetse ga bo go na le tsela e a e dirisang ka teng le ene. Le fa go ntse jalo, o ne a ikutlwa gore dilo tse a di bogisang di ka se nne sepe. Ga ba a tshwanela go nna le boitshwaro jo bo sa siamang, e bile ga ba kitla ba tlhola ba go tlhabisa ditlhong. Le fa go ntse jalo, mongwe le mongwe wa ditsala tsa gagwe o tshwanetse go nna le ditsala tsa gagwe tse dintsi. Le fa go ntse jalo, o tshwanetse go nna le tlotlo e e sa tshwanelang go nna le lorato lwa gagwe, mme o tshwanetse go nonotsha kamano ya gagwe. Le fa go ntse jalo, dirisa tlhaloganyo ya gago ka go buisana le ene ka se ke se go boleletseng. O tshwanetse go itse gore ke eng se se tla dirang gore o nne le diphelelo tse di molemo go di gaisa tsotlhe. Mme nna ga ke a ka ka nna wa tshwenyega ka pelo ya me, mme go tswa mo pelong ya me ke ne ke dumela gore e ka tswa e le tirelo, ke ka bo ke sa ikwatlhaela go go utlwisa botlhoko ka ntlha eno ka ntlha ya pitlagano ya lelapa la me, e ka tswa e kete e ka bo e ikaeletse go ikgodisa ka ditshenyegelo tsa ba bangwe."

ty: " Tei mua ia outou to'na huru i teie nei ; E mea moni, e mea ino a'e mea ino roa'tu i na mea e piti nei. Ma te ite i teie mau mea atoa, mai ta ' u i ite i teie nei e rave rahi hebedoma, a feruri na eaha to ' u mana'o i to ' u iteraa i to outou tuahine i te hereraa ia ' na mai tei ore i itehia a'enei, e i to ' u papuraa e e faaipoipo o ' na ia ' na: a feruri na eaha ta ' u i ite no outou atoa. I to'u haereraa'tu ia oe ra i te hepetoma i ma'iri a'e nei e to'u iteraa ia oe o oe ana'e, ua tupu te hinaaro i roto ia'u ia ite i te parau mau ; noa'tu e, aita outou i ite eaha te rave ia itehia ana'e te reira. E mea huru √™ paha to'u huru i taua taime ra ; i teie nei r√¢, e maramarama √Øa outou i te reira. Ia faati'a ia outou paatoa ia haavarehia ; ia hi'o i to oe tuahine ‚Äì eaha r√¢ ta'u e nehenehe e rave ? Aita to'u e ti'aturiraa e, e manu√Øa vau ; e i te tahi taime ua mana'o vau e, e riro paha te faa√ªruraa o to outou tuahine i te faaino ia'na. I teie nei r√¢, i muri a'e i teie huru faaohiparaa haama, o te nehenehe e faaite e eaha ta ' na mau opuaraa i nia ia ' na. Noa'tu r√¢ te huru o to'na oraraa, i teie nei, e mea pap√ª roa e, e fariu mai oia ma te mauruuru no to'na iho huru, ia faaau ana'e oia i te reira i to to'u taata veve o Eliza, ia hi'o ana'e oia i te huru oraraa ino e te ti'aturi ore o teie tamahine veve, e ia faaite oia ia'na iho, ma te here rahi ia'na, e te puai mai to'na iho,  e na roto i te ho√™ feruriraa tei haamauiui ia'na iho‚Äì o te ti'a ia haapa'o ia'na i roto i to'na oraraa. Papu maitai e e faaohipahia teie faaauraa e o ' na. E ite oia e e mea faufaa ore to ' na iho mau mauiui. E ere ratou i te haerea tia ore, e eita ta ratou e nehenehe e hopoi mai i te haama. Area r√¢, e ti'a i te mau hoa atoa ia faariro ia ratou ei hoa rahi a'e no'na. E tia i te tapitapiraa no to ' na oaoa ore, e te faatura i to ' na puai i raro a'e i te reira, ia haapaari i te mau taairaa atoa. A faaohipa r√¢ i to outou iho paari no te faaite ia ' na i ta ' u i parau atu ia outou. E ti'a ia outou ia ite maitai i te mea e tupu mai ; ahani r√¢ aita vau i haapa'o maitai, e ua ti'aturi to'u aau e e nehenehe te reira e riro ei taviniraa, e faaiti i to'na mau tatarahaparaa, eita √Øa vau e faati'a ia'u iho ia haape'ape'a ia oe no te mau ati o to'u nei utuafare, e te ho√™ faahitiraa parau tei opuahia no te faateitei ia'u iho i ni'a i te tua o vetahi √™ ".
mg: Ny toetrany dia eo anatrehanao; Lafo, lafo vidy, ary ratsy kokoa noho izy roa ireo. Noho ny fahafantarana izany rehetra izany, araka ny efa nahafantarako azy nandritra ny herinandro maro, dia fantaro izay mety ho tsapako tamin'ny fahitana ny rahavavinao ho tia azy toy ny hatramin'izay, ary rehefa nahazo toky aho fa hanambady azy izy: fantaro izay mety ho tsapako noho ny aminareo rehetra. Rehefa tonga tany aminareo aho tamin'ny herinandro lasa ka nahita anareo irery, dia tapa-kevitra ny hahafantatra ny marina; Na dia tsy manapa-kevitra ny amin'izay tokony hatao rehefa fantatra izany. Tsy maintsy ho toa hafahafa taminao ny fihetsiko tamin'izany fotoana izany; Fa ankehitriny dia ho azonao tsara izany. Mba hamela anareo rehetra ho voafitaka; Mamangy ny rahavavinao‚Äîsaingy inona no azoko atao? Tsy nanana fanantenana ny hitsabaka amin'ny fahombiazana aho; ary indraindray aho dia nieritreritra fa mety mbola hitaky azy indray ny fitaoman'ny rahavavinao. Fa ankehitriny, taorian'ny fampiasana mahamenatra toy izany, iza no afaka milaza ny fikasany momba azy. Na inona na inona mety ho vitan'izy ireo, na izany aza, dia mety hitodika amin'ny fankasitrahana ny toe-pahasalamany manokana izy amin'izao fotoana izao, raha mampitaha izany amin'ny an'i Eliza mahantra, rehefa mandinika ny toe-javatra mampalahelo sy tsy misy fanantenana iainan'ity tovovavy mahantra ity izy, ary maka sary azy amin'ny tenany, miaraka amin'ny fitiavana azy matanjaka, mbola matanjaka tahaka ny azy,  ary amin'ny saina mijaly noho ny tena-fanaratsiana, izay tsy maintsy manatrika azy amin'ny alalan'ny fiainana. Azo antoka fa tsy maintsy mampiasa azy io fampitahana io. Ho tsapany fa tsy misy dikany ny fijaliany. Tsy manao ratsy izy ireo, ary tsy afaka mitondra henatra. Fa ny namana rehetra dia tsy maintsy ho lasa namany bebe kokoa amin'ny alalan'izy ireo. Tsy maintsy manamafy ny firaiketam - po rehetra ny fiahiana ny tsy fahasambarana sy ny fanajana ny herim - pony eo ambanin'izany. Mitenena amin'ny vadinao anefa izay nolazaiko taminao. Tokony ho fantatrao tsara hoe inona no ho vokatr'izany; fa raha tsy matotra aho, ary mino avy ao am-poko fa mety ho asa fanompoana izany, mety hampihena ny nenina, dia tsy ho namela ny tenako hanakorontana anareo amin'ity tantaran'ny fahorian'ny fianakaviako ity aho, amin'ny alalan'ny fitanisana izay mety ho natao mba hanabeazana ny tenako ho an'ny hafa."

Tsy dia tsara fanahy loatra ny rahalahinao sy ny anabavinao! Nefa tsy milaza na inona na inona hanameloka azy ireo aho; ary mba hahazoana antoka fa nalefany hody izahay tao anatin' ny kalesiny ihany, izay mihoatra noho izay notadiaviko. Ary natahotra aho noho ny tahotra ny rahavavinao hangataka aminay ny amin'ireo vehivavy izay nomeny anay andro iray na roa talohan'izay; nefa tsy nisy nambara ny amin'ireo, ka dia nitandrina aho mba tsy ho hitan'ny masoko. Edward dia manana raharaham-barotra ao Oxford, hoy izy; ka tsy maintsy mandeha any mandritra ny fotoana fohy izy; ary aorian'izany, raha vao afaka manazava ny Eveka izy, dia hotokanana. Manontany tena aho hoe inona no ho azony amin'izany!‚ÄîTsara fanahy! (Mihomehy izy rehefa miteny) Hametraka ny fiainako aho ary fantatro izay holazain'ny zanaky ny mpiray tampo amiko, rehefa ren'izy ireo izany. en: "You are very much mistaken. I do assure you that you owe it entirely, at least almost entirely, to your own merit, and Colonel Brandon's discernment of it. I have had no hand in it. I did not even know, till I understood his design, that the living was vacant; nor had it ever occurred to me that he might have had such a living in his gift. As a friend of mine, of my family, he may, perhaps‚Äîindeed I know he HAS, still greater pleasure in bestowing it; but, upon my word, you owe nothing to my solicitation."

en: "Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her. The merest awkward country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.‚Äî I remember her perfectly. Just the kind of girl I should suppose likely to captivate poor Edward. I offered immediately, as soon as my mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing, for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it till after the breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you know, to interfere. But had I been informed of it a few hours earlier‚ÄîI think it is most probable‚Äîthat something might have been hit on. I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very strong light. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help thinking, in short, that means might have been found. But now it is all too late. He must be starved, you know;‚Äîthat is certain; absolutely starved."
